folder: Rockland Avenue & Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
(1)
Rockland Avenue, north side, 600 yards east of Richmond Avenue (vantage point), showing the lane that runs north from Rockland Avenue into the property of Charles H. Blair. The lane is popularly known as Corson's Lane, after Corson who owned the property prior to Blair. In the background is visible the farmhouse.

By Wm. T. Davis through P. L. Sperr
November 2, 1922

(2)
A closer view of the farmhouse.

November 2, 1922
P. L. Sperr

(3)
A later view of the lane and farmhouse. The house is 500 yards north of Rockland Avenue.

P. L. Sperr
June 20, 1926

folder: Rockland Avenue & Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
(1)
Rockland Avenue, south side, 600 yards east of Richmond Avenue, showing the old Oscar Prall House, the wing of which
dates back to colonial times.
1924
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The same, from the opposite direction.
1924
P. L. Sperr

folder: Rockland Avenue & Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
Rockland Avenue, south side, 300 yards east of Richmond Avenue, showing the house of the present Oscar Prall.

Spring, 1924

P. L. Sperr

folder: Rockland Avenue & Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
(1)
Rockland Avenue, north side, 600 yards east of Richmond Avenue, showing a frame dwelling along the lane that leads into the property of Charles H. Blair from Rockland Avenue, opposite the old Oscar Prall House. The lane is popularly known as Corson's Lane, after the owner of the property, who owned it before Blair.

June 20, 1926

P. L. Sperr

(2)
A barn on the Blair proprerty, along Corson's Lane.

July 18, 1926

P. L. Sperr

folder: Rockland Avenue & Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
Rockland Avenue, north side, 600 yards east of Richmond Avenue. This farmhouse is situated 500 yards back of the avenue, on the lane--popularly known as Corson's Lane--running into the Charles H. Blair propehty, formerly owned by Corson. The lane is opposite the old Oscar Prall
House.
July 18, 1926
P. L. Sperr
(2)
The same, another view.
June 20, 1926
P. L. Sperr

folder: Richmond Avenue & Rockland Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
Richmond Avenue, west side, north from near Rockland Avenue.

P. L. Sperr

April 25, 1929

folder: Richmond Avenue & Rockland Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
2045 Richmond Avenue, east side, north of Rockland Avenue. The house was owned by W. H. Mesler from 1898 to 1907, according to Robinson's maps of the above years.

May 19, 1932

P. L. Sperr

folder: Richmond Avenue & Rockland Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
(1) Richmond Avenue, east side, between Rockland Avenue and Signs Road, showing Public School No. 27.

P. L. Sperr
May 19, 1932

(2) The library story hour at Public School No. 27. Miss Hill, librarian, is the story teller.

P. L. Sperr
August 22, 1940

folder: Rockland Avenue & Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
Rockland Avenue, north side, about 350 yards east of Richmond Avenue. The house and property was owned by Adam Martin Sr. from 1898 to 1907, and by Herman Weisman in 1917. Dates refer to maps on which the owners' names appear.

May 19, 1932

P. L. Sperr

folder: Richmond Avenue & Rockland Avenue, Staten Island, NY
text:
(1) 2141 Richmond Avenue, at the S.E. corner of Rockland Avenue, showing the Gerald Darcey house (1917 map). From 1874 to 1898 it was owned by Decker, and in 1907 by Pearl W. Hokes.
November 2, 1922
Wm. T. Davis through P. L. Sperr

(2) Another view of the house viewed northward toward Rockland Avenue. The house in the center of the view is at the N.E. corner of the two avenues.
April 25, 1929
P. L. Sperr

(3) An additional view at a later date.
August 1, 1937
P. L. Sperr
